text:
MILES PERKINS: Hello,
I'm Miles Perkins,

And this is where
we go beyond what's

on the screen to
explore what really

drives the most creative minds
in the real-time industry.

Today, we'll explore how game
experiences are built and scaled

in Fortnite and how
brands can leverage

this to connect with
millions of audience members
in a very authentic way.

Kasper Weber is helping shape
the future of gaming and branded
entertainment.
And he's just getting started.

He's the founder and CEO
of Beyond Creative, one

of the most featured teams
in Fortnite Creative.

And he's also a
former solo creator

whose games have reached
over 100 million players.

Kasper now leads
brand collaborations

with names like Mentos, Ralph
Lauren, and The Tonight Show,
just to name a few.

In this conversation, we talk
about building creative careers,

making engaging
digital experiences,

and how gaming is the new
frontier for storytelling
and brand connection.
Kasper, thanks for joining me.

When did you first realize
that you were creative

and that gaming
would be your canvas?

KASPER WEBER: actually
have to go very far

back because I actually
built my very first game when
I was just 10.

So I was like, I've always
been playing my dad's huge
into computers and stuff.

So ever since I was
3, sitting on his lap
playing video games with him.

But when I was 10, I was using
something called GameMaker.

And I was, like, building
my own platform and games.

And then, I've been touching
on all sorts of different game

ecosystems, if you will,
and Counter-Strike as well.

But yeah, I really,
really fell in love
with Fortnite Creative in 2018.

MILES PERKINS: So 2018, you fall
in love with Fortnite Creative.

And at that point, I mean,
what were your thoughts?

Was it just like a
passion for playing
or did you see something bigger?

KASPER WEBER: I
think it's a passion

for creating and building
something that I want.

So when I first
started, I actually
worked with some YouTubers.

And there's been something
similar in Minecraft

where YouTubers would be
recording videos on those games.

And I was like,
surely that's going

to happen with Fortnite now
that you can build anything.

So I was like, hey, I'm
pitching three ideas.

And they ended up
taking one of them.

And then, I was
just like, oh, cool.

This YouTuber that
I'm looking up to
wants to play my game on video.
And then, that led to the other.

And then, we ended up doing,
like, 75 games in just one year.
MILES PERKINS: Oh, wow.
KASPER WEBER: Yeah.

MILES PERKINS: When
you say we, who is we?

KASPER WEBER: So that's
technically just me.
[LAUGHTER]
One man army.
MILES PERKINS: Proverbial we.
KASPER WEBER: Yes, yes.

No, they had some
ideas too, right?

MILES PERKINS: So
in those early days

before you were doing this, when
did you start to realize that,
hey, wait a minute.

This actually might
be a vocation.
This might be a business.
KASPER WEBER: I was in April.
So we were five months into it.

I'm studying
software development

at the University
of IT in Copenhagen.

And I realized that you
could get featured and earn

from supported creator and
actually make a living from it.

So I was one of the fortunate
creators to get a feature,
as we called it, way back.

And that allowed the funds for
me to go all in on one year

and just say, I'm going
to give it my all.

And that's eventually what
kicked off everything.
So yeah, that was April 2019.
MILES PERKINS: Oh, wow.
So that was--

I guess that means
that you're creating.

And it pretty much is staying
within the creative ecosystem.
Fast forward to UEFN coming out.

What's your thought
at that point?

KASPER WEBER: At UEFN, we had
actually scaled the studio
to be more than 15 people.

So it was more the creative
product, game design.
Like, I more had an eye on it.

But when UEFN came on and
became like such a game changer

that it became, I didn't really
do all the programming anymore.

I'm still touching it, still
moving some props around.

But all the technicalities that
we have experts in that now.
MILES PERKINS: OK.

So as you're getting this going,
you're starting to do this.

You're operating
within the ecosystem.

At what point did you
actually start that company?

I mean, really take me back and
take me through the process.
KASPER WEBER: Yeah.

MILES PERKINS: Especially
in the context of maybe

there are other
creators out there

that are trying to figure
out, how can I be like Kasper?
Like, what is it?
What was that path for you.

KASPER WEBER: I think
I've just always tried

and it's always been like
building games and games
and games.

Your first game may
not be the success.

But then, you go on to the next
game and the next game again.

And in my case, I was
fortunate to be recognized.

So back in 2019, there was the
Fortnite Creative World Cup

Hollywood Game Jam, something,
a really big thing at the time.

And we're building games for
the Fortnite Creative World Cup.

I think there was
a $5 million prize
pool dedicated to these games.
We had four days.
That's a lot of pressure.

But ultimately, like, the
passion for creating these games

and meeting fellow
creators in the ecosystem,
we were like 16 builders.
So we met.

And yeah, one of those
actually ended up

being my co-founder
in the studio.

So after the World
Cup happening in '19,

we realized there's a lot
of brands, a lot of IPs,

a lot of artists that are
interested in this ecosystem

because they saw
what we now could do.

So we founded a company with
the main goal of really building

the games with the
brands we look up

to that we wish we
would experience if we
were the players, which we are.
MILES PERKINS: Interesting OK.

And so I think that's
fascinating also

because one of the things that
I want to understand better

is the ecosystem of
brands that are coming in.

You guys have created something
that engages with these brands

and creates these
kinds of experiences.

I mean, did you
initially know, yeah,

that's the thing
that I'm going to do?
Or did you trip across it?
Or how did that come into being?

KASPER WEBER: I think
we were really--

we felt very fulfilled
working with the brands
that we've looked up to.

And our very first
brand was, I believe,
working with the Nickelodeon.

And I'm like, oh,
what's that way back.
That's so cool.

So yeah, we had a
lot of fulfillment.

And being just three and
seeing the demand that came in,

we really wanted to
pass on that opportunity
down to other creators.

And we were fortunate to
have a community behind us.

So Liam and myself and
our last co-founder,

Tommy, we all had
YouTube channels
on our own respective areas.

So we had around
100,000 gameplay.

I was recording myself
playing these games
with those YouTubers.
I started with.

Liam, he had 120,000
followers and doing art.

So he built the most
ambitious projects.

And other creators would
be like, what is he doing?

We're still battling
that with memory today.

Always building
things 80% too big.
MILES PERKINS: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

KASPER WEBER: And then,
Tommy, he had a good chunk,

60,000 followers or
something on programming.

And we were like, that's
three different areas
we can go together.

And then, our very
first hires, when

I talk about passing down
the opportunity of working

with brands, came from
our own community.
MILES PERKINS: OK.

And you guys really
reached out to one another.

You knew each other
on the outside.
Or how was that?

KASPER WEBER: Yeah, we knew
each other in the ecosystem.

So before me and Liam
met at the World Cup,

we had spoken on Discord hours
on end every day for, I think,
three or four months.

And then, that
opportunity arised.
And we were like, oh, what?
It's LA.
It's cool.

Why don't we go there,
like, four days before
and just hang out?

I didn't know what
he looked like.

Yeah, let's get
a hotel together.
We can share a room.
Sure.

So it's like, I end up
standing there in the airport.

Someone's tapping
me on my shoulder.

And I'm like, who
are these guys?

And they're like, the
voice is familiar.
MILES PERKINS: Right.

KASPER WEBER: Oh, you
are [INAUDIBLE] Yeah.
MILES PERKINS: That's awesome.

KASPER WEBER: So I
ended up going to LA,

Crusty's, hanging
out with some guys

that I met virtually here
building Fortnite games.
And we were just all super--

are super passionate
about everything
that we do in this space.

MILES PERKINS: You know,
that word that you say,
their passion.

One of the things that I
really like to talk about

is the technology is
great and enables.

People always push
beyond the technology.

But it's the passion that makes
something that people really
connect with.

Talk a little bit about
what that passion is for you

and how that passion also
relates to the business.

KASPER WEBER: Yeah,
I mean, the passion,

I feel like you can see
the passion in the product.

And to be a good business,
you need a good product.

So if you don't have
passionate people,
I feel like you can just tell.

It's like you're crossing
off a list of key features
you just need to have.

Of course, you need
that list crossed.

But I feel like you need
something more, something

that shows you have attention
to detail, whether it's

Easter eggs, whether it's
some story around the game.

And also to pull off some
of these big projects,

you just need to work hours and
hours on end, especially when
you're not 15 like we are now.

But when we were
just starting out,

we had to pull long
nights and long days.

So to get to where we are today,
it just took a lot of passion.
MILES PERKINS: Yeah.

But I mean, the other part is
those long days, long nights,
I'm curious.

If you didn't have the
project, would you still
be doing that anyway?
KASPER WEBER: I was.
MILES PERKINS: Yeah, yeah.
KASPER WEBER: I was.

I was building for the ecosystem
and had an unhealthy amount
of Fortnite hours I would say.
I was more than a full-time job.

That was a full-time job
and a half I would say.

Well, that's because
you go to bed.
And you can't sleep.

You're thinking about what's
the next game I'm going to do.

And you're just excited
to wake up the next day
to start on that game.

That's the type of magic that I
think an ecosystem like Fortnite

is allowing the next generation
of developers to have
or creators.

MILES PERKINS: So
I think as we start

to look at some of the different
forms of entertainment,

of creativity, of
design, can you

tell me a little
bit about what are

the fundamental things as
you look at your creative
to process?

What are the fundamental
things that you

feel that you need to have
in order to be creative?

Like, some directors, they come
from an emotional point of view.
And they really want to connect.

Some people connect to the
story a little bit more.

What are the things
that really drive

you to create a playable game
that people haven't seen before
and generate a lot of fun?

KASPER WEBER: I
think the best thing

about creating the
games is actually
seeing players play them.

Or if there's marketing
budgets behind the brand,

seeing your favorite
influencer play the game.

So when we build
our games, we always

aim to put the
player first, always
in the player's interests.
What do they want?

Because although as great as
Fortnite and the ecosystem is,

there's a lot of
experiences out there.

And if you're not giving
them exactly what they're
looking for, someone else will.

So we always want
to build around what
do the players genuinely want?
And how can we best meet that?

But I would say actually
seeing the players play

the game and maybe
even in voice chat,

hearing them whenever
they're frustrated,

whenever they're
happy, whenever they're
cheering that's so much fun.

MILES PERKINS: Oh,
that's awesome.
Yeah.

You talked about also
the process of you

and your two co-founders
of being on YouTube

and showing people your
process as you're building.
KASPER WEBER: Yes.

MILES PERKINS: I find that
to be also really fascinating

because a lot of creative people
live for the process, not always

for the end result.
Can you tell me

a little bit about that
community that was built

and how you guys built
around the process?

KASPER WEBER: We-- when we made
a Fortnite game, a lot of it

was based on our YouTube
channels as well.

So we would drive the
community into those games.

And we would actually
collaborate as well.

So Liam and myself and actually
our friend, our colleague,

Chad Mustard, from Chicago,
he was an immature gamer.

We used to do like these
four-hour build challenges

where we would take a random
topic, give ourselves four hours
and see how far we got.

And then, we would
actually share that game
with our community.

So it was kind of like
built for the community.

MILES PERKINS: That
sounds like a lot of fun.

KASPER WEBER: That
was a lot of fun.
MILES PERKINS: Yeah.

KASPER WEBER: And we
had a spinning wheel.
So it landed on a certain theme.
And then, we had to do it.

And then the community
would suggest themes for us.
MILES PERKINS: So now, OK.
Fast forward.
You stand up Beyond Creative.

You've now engaged
with Nickelodeon.

KASPER WEBER: I was not
at Beyond Creative but.
MILES PERKINS: Oh, it wasn't?
OK.
That was before--
KASPER WEBER: That's before--

we weren't even established
as Beyond Creative.

That was with a whole other
set of guys just learning this.

And we just had
such fulfillment.

So we ended up
eventually deciding, hey,
we want to build a studio.
MILES PERKINS: OK.
KASPER WEBER: Yeah.

MILES PERKINS: So tell
me about that process.

So you have success
with the Nickelodeon.
And then, what happens?

KASPER WEBER: What
happens is that we

need to learn how to do a
business and all the logistics,
all the managerial things.
And that's a process.
That's about the process.

That's not a
destination you reach.
Then, something else comes up.
And you need to learn that.

But no, it started
off just being,

like, three to five guys just
building, splitting whatever

income there was and
not really thinking

so much about any numbers
or anything in that sense

and just having a lot of joy
working with the brands we all

look up to and seeing
our influencers

or our favorite
influencers playing it.

So that was the transition
that had to be--
that we went through.

MILES PERKINS: So I think also
the interesting part is you

and Beyond Creative engage
with brands that you think fit.
Right?

Can you tell me a
little bit about some

of those first experiences
you had working with brands?

Because I know a
little bit about what

we refer to as the
advertising agency or kind
of process and methodologies.

That was probably a
bit eye opening to you.

KASPER WEBER:
Yeah, no, I mean, I

had no idea about the whole sort
of, like, advertising industry

and how everything was
connected or layered.

What we do is we try to always
work with the brand in the most
authentic way to the platform.

Not every brand is
dealt the same cards.

So it's about figuring out
what cards do they have?

What do they allow
in the Fortnite game?

And how can we best not fit the
players into what they allow,
but fit them into what exists?

So not, of course, not doing
it in a way where we just make
a game and put some logos on.
It needs to be more than that.

Otherwise, it's
not going to work.

So we always try to think,
what can we do with the brand
that we do have?

And that's not the
same for every brand.

MILES PERKINS:
Authenticity yeah?
KASPER WEBER: Yes.
MILES PERKINS: Yeah.

I mean, I think the thing
that I'm seeing out there

is that the traditional
advertising, there's
an economy for the audience.
I will give you something.

And in turn, I'll
watch your thing.

But you're talking
about something else

where you're giving
something that is something
that is really entertaining--
KASPER WEBER: Yeah.

MILES PERKINS:
--regardless of the brand.
KASPER WEBER: Yeah.

So, I mean, if you
think about television,

you're watching a show,
60 Minutes or whatever,

and then there's a
10-minute ad break,

are you sitting through
watching the full 10 minutes?

Where in Fortnite, if you do
it in a very authentic way

and an engaging way
and a gamified way,

the players may
play with the brand.

It's not your 30-second slot
in that 10-minute duration.

It's like, no, you
get 15, 30, 45 minutes

of potential game engagement
on a platform like Fortnite.

And I think that's
super eye-opening.

And I think that's a transition
we hopefully will see more
of in the next, 3, 5, 10 years.

MILES PERKINS: I'd also imagine
that's a bit challenging,

though, for the
brands themselves.

Because sometimes
what's fun about a brand

might be the thing that is a bit
tongue in cheek about the brand.
Right?

It might be that
they exist in a way

that with a certain demographic
that isn't necessarily
how they position themselves.
How do you navigate that?
KASPER WEBER: That's true.

I think, in general,
most brands should

be very open to exploring
what way they best

fit into a certain game because
how they fit into Fortnite

might be different to how
they fit into another game.

And a really cool project we
did with BBH and MetaVision

here for an integration
in an existing game
was we built a Mentos bazooka.

That's the first
custom branded weapon.

And it's, like, it's
skinning the 3D model on top
of a Fortnite rocket launcher.

So players are actually
using this item, weapon,
non-lethal weapon.

But they're using it in an
existing game, multiple existing
games.

And they're just
having fun with it.

So I think that's an example
of both agency and brand really

going in a direction that is
really authentic to what players
like in Fortnite.

MILES PERKINS: And
there wasn't any desire

to even do some cross branding
with a certain soda company?

KASPER WEBER: I am not
in those conversations.

But that could have
been really cool.

That could have
been really cool.

MILES PERKINS: Yeah, I mean,
but I mean, I joke about that.
But that's the thing--

KASPER WEBER: I would
have loved that.
MILES PERKINS: --audience.
Because you are the audience.

I mean, that's the
thing I think that you

bring to the table is
you're very much the player.
You're the demographic.

KASPER WEBER: Yeah, that is very
much the position that we take.

And what I think
makes us very unique.
We're very niche in Fortnite.

This is our expertise,
or UEFN if you will.

And we started out being
just Fortnite creators.

And when UEFN came
around, we started hiring
more UE devs or creators.

But we were very
particular on finding

the ones that had an existing
passion for Fortnite.

So there may be someone that's
working in another AAA studio.
But they really like Fortnite.

And they want to do cool
stuff around Fortnite.

And then, they're
a great fit for us.

So today, I'm very
proud that we have

a really good balance between
half-half Fortnite creators

and Fortnite-- or sorry,
Fortnite creators and UE
developers.

So we learn from
the UE developers
how to best utilize the engine.

And we teach them what they
don't know about Fortnite.
So that's a nice dynamic there.
MILES PERKINS: Yeah, no.

That, I mean, I
think that is great.

It feels much more
authentic than some

of the scenarios that you
have where something's
kind of being forced in.
KASPER WEBER: Yeah.
Yeah, no.
No, it's not forced.

But we do play forced
Fortnite every Friday.
We have 2-hour session.

It's called Friday Fun
or Feedback Friday,
depends on what we're playing.

MILES PERKINS: Which is,
again, very important
I think to the product.

KASPER WEBER: We need to
see what's going around.

And if you're not doing
it over the weekend,

we're dedicating
2 hours on Friday

where you can see what's
the coolest innovation?

What did some other creator
make that's super cool?
How can we direct inspiration?
Or what can we do better?
Or really just seeing.

MILES PERKINS: So UEFN, one of
the things about those tools

and the UE tools is Fortnite
has a certain look to it.
Right?
And it's a very distinct look.
UEFN allows you to do anything.

It really unleashes
Unreal to give it
any look that you want to have.
KASPER WEBER: Yes.

MILES PERKINS: But I
would imagine there still

is a little bit of a
tension between the people

who are coming to play Fortnite
and something looking completely
different.

KASPER WEBER: Yeah, we don't
want to throw the player off.
So they want to play, usually--

it depends on the demographic
within Fortnite as well.

Some players like
hyper realistic stuff.

We saw that with
the body cam trend.

Some players want to
play more stylized stuff.

So it depends on the type of
game that you're trying to make.

A lot of brands really want to
make very hyper realistic stuff.
So we've done that.

But I think there's also some
brands that's looking more
in the stylized way.

It really depends on
the game and the brand.

In terms of the transition from
Fortnite Creative 1.0 to now,

as you say, we can
do so much more now.

And one of the very
first UEFN experiences

we made for a brand was a
racing game where you raced
against a Honda, a Honda car.
And that Honda car was 3D model.
It was perfect.

But what you don't know is
that in Fortnite Creative 1.0,

we were manually building the
Honda enlarge out of 4,000
cubes.

And when you were
asked, hey, can we
change the slope a little bit?

That's like 300
squares I'm moving.
It's way different now.
It's way better.
And we had the same issues then.

MILES PERKINS: Well,
I actually find

that fascinating because no
matter what, you were doing it.

KASPER WEBER: No,
we were doing it.

MILES PERKINS: Yeah,
no matter what.

And I think that that's
really the cool thing

is that you have people that
are always pushing the tool

because they're always trying
to do something that is new
and hasn't been done before.
KASPER WEBER: Yeah.

MILES PERKINS: Is
that one of the parts
of the DNA of who you guys are?

KASPER WEBER: We
wanted to do more than

what Creative is part--
like, what Creative unlocks.

So it's always been like
in Fortnite Creative 1.0,

it's maybe a bit
easier than now.

But we wanted to
always push what can we
do that hasn't been done?

And that may be creating
a large-scale product.
It may be building a car.

Right now, it may be making
your own drivable car

in a way that
doesn't feel hacky.

So we're just always trying to
find ways that we can do more.

And with the vision that
we hear about whenever

we come to Unreal Fest for
these state of Unreal Keynotes

it's super exciting
to see what is

going to be beyond Fortnite
or beyond Creative?
What's going to be after?

That's something we're
very excited about.
MILES PERKINS: OK.
So you guys create airship wars.

And you reach over 116
million minutes played.
KASPER WEBER: Yes.
MILES PERKINS: Right?

So I want to know
about finding the fun.

Because clearly within
that, you found the fun.
People were in there.
How do you do that?
You know what I mean?
And is it fresh?

Is it older game mechanics
that are rethought of?
Or how do you approach that?
KASPER WEBER: That was--

I would say that's a game
genre that's been rethought of.

And it also goes back to our DNA
of doing something most people
wouldn't.

So that airship wars,
which has had many names

from blimps to pirate
ships to spaceships,
so it's built out of planks.
We placed every plank manually.

I don't know how many
planks there are.
But they're placed manually.

And that's because that
allows us to destroy the ship.

So you can-- it's a
red-versus-blue game,
which is a very popular genre.

But this game allows
you to take on the ship
from different places.

Like you can explode your
way through different floors

to go down to these
reactors where,

if you eliminate all three
reactors, you win the game.

So it's just a different
way of red-versus-blue

but where you can destroy the
entire ship if you want to.

And that doesn't exist if you go
into most team deathmatch games

now, you can't really
destroy the environment.

But this one was
fully destructible.

MILES PERKINS: Oh,
that's awesome.

KASPER WEBER: Yeah,
that is really cool.

MILES PERKINS:
Yeah, and people--

I mean, I would imagine
just that newness of that
really got people excited.
KASPER WEBER: It did.

And we saw people making their
way into the ship in ways

we were like, wow,
we need to fix this.

MILES PERKINS: So one of
the other things that--

let's talk back
about the brands.

I would imagine the brands don't
all the way understand this.

They understand that
they want, if not need,
to be in these spaces.

And they need to know it
in a really authentic way,

not just as a, OK, I'm going
to throw money on the table.
Go do stuff.

KASPER WEBER: Yeah,
that's exactly it.

It's not build it
and they will come.

No, you need to build it
for them for them to come.
MILES PERKINS: Yeah.
OK.

So let's think about
looking forward.

So as someone who knows this
platform incredibly well

and actually understands
Fortnite as a platform,

what are you excited
about moving forward?
KASPER WEBER: Mobile.
MILES PERKINS: OK.
KASPER WEBER: Yeah, mobile.
